docs.abstract: Jane Brody's Personal Health column examines some behavorial risk factors for breast cancer and simple adjustments in life styles that can help women reduce them; discusses importance of diet, exercise and avoidance of cigarettes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is hope for the millions of women who worry about getting breast cancer. A fatalistic attitude that either you will get it or you will not is no longer justified. There is fast-growing evidence that simple adjustments in the way one lives can help reduce the risk of developing this increasingly common disease. You have no doubt heard about the risk factors for breast cancer that you can do little or nothing about: starting to menstruate at a young age, entering menopause at a late age, never having had a child or having a first birth after the age of 30, having a mother, sister or maternal aunt who had breast cancer and inheriting one of the genes that are now known to account for familial breast cancer. You may have been bombarded as well by claims, thus far wholly unproved, that environmental contaminants may be causing the rise in breast cancer, which now strikes one American woman in eight sometime in her life.
